lecture: Lecture 2: Core Concepts of Artificial Intelligence

questions.question: Which of these best describes Artificial Intelligence (AI)?

options.A: The field that builds systems to simulate or extend human intelligence in real-world tasks

questions.question: What is Machine Learning (ML)?

options.A: Algorithms that learn from data to improve performance without explicit programming

questions.question: How is Deep Learning (DL) related to Machine Learning and AI?

options.A: Deep Learning ⊂ Machine Learning ⊂ AI

questions.question: Which statement about Deep Learning is correct?

options.A: A subset of ML that uses multi-layer neural networks to learn rich representations
options.C: Only used for computer vision tasks

questions.question: What is the correct hierarchical relationship among these fields?

options.A: AI (broadest) → ML (subset) → DL (subset of ML)

questions.question: What characterizes Narrow or Weak AI?

options.A: Specialized in performing a single task
options.B: Has human-level intelligence across all domains
options.D: Can perform any intellectual task a human can

questions.question: Which of these is an example of Narrow AI?

options.A: Siri or Alexa voice assistants
options.B: A hypothetical system with human-level general intelligence

questions.question: What does General or Strong AI refer to?

options.A: Hypothetical systems with human-level intelligence across all intellectual tasks

questions.question: Superintelligent AI is best described as:

options.A: A theoretical AI that surpasses human intelligence across all domains
options.B: Current AI systems we use daily
options.D: AI that can only react to current inputs

questions.question: Which capability-based AI type describes most current AI systems?

options.A: Narrow or Weak AI

questions.question: What characterizes Reactive Machines?

options.A: Basic AI with no memory, only responding to current input
options.B: AI that uses past data to make decisions

questions.question: Which AI functionality type uses past data to make decisions?

options.A: Limited Memory AI

questions.question: Where is Limited Memory AI commonly found?

options.A: Self-driving cars

questions.question: What is Theory of Mind AI (still in development)?

options.A: AI that understands emotions, beliefs, and intentions of others
options.C: AI that only reacts to current inputs

questions.question: Which functionality-based AI type is purely hypothetical?

options.A: Self-aware AI

questions.question: Which school of AI is based on rules, logic, and symbols?

options.A: Symbolism (Symbolic AI)

questions.question: What is an example of Symbolism?

options.A: Expert systems and rule-based reasoning

questions.question: Which school is inspired by the human brain and learns from data using interconnected nodes?

options.A: Connectionism

questions.question: What are examples of Connectionism?

options.A: Deep learning, ANN, CNN, RNN

questions.question: Which school focuses on agent behavior and responses to the environment (stimulus-action)?

options.A: Behaviorism

questions.question: What is an example of Behaviorism?

options.A: Reinforcement learning, robotics

questions.question: What does NLP stand for and what does it do?

options.A: Natural Language Processing - enables computers to understand and generate human languages
options.B: Neural Language Programming - creates neural networks
options.C: Natural Learning Process - learns from nature
options.D: Network Language Protocol - manages network communications

questions.question: Which of these is NOT an NLP application?

options.A: Sentiment analysis

questions.question: What is Computer Vision (CV)?

options.A: Technology that gives machines the ability to 'see' and understand visual information

questions.question: Which CV task involves partitioning an image into multiple segments?

options.A: Image Segmentation

questions.question: What does Object Detection do?

options.A: Detects and locates objects in images

questions.question: What is the process of following a specific object's movement across video frames?

options.A: Object Tracking

questions.question: What does OCR stand for and what does it do?

options.A: Optical Character Recognition - recognizes text in images and converts to editable text
options.B: Optical Computer Recognition - recognizes computers in images
options.D: Optical Character Reading - reads aloud text

questions.question: What are the three key elements needed for AI development according to the lecture?

options.A: Data, Algorithms, Computing Power

questions.question: Which industry applications were mentioned for AI technologies?

options.A: Healthcare, Finance, Transportation, Entertainment

questions.question: What development stages were mentioned for NLP?

options.A: Rules/linguistics → ML/DL → Large Language Models (LLMs)

questions.question: Which of these is a Computer Vision task that helps in medical imaging to isolate tumors?

options.A: Image Segmentation

questions.question: In autonomous driving, which CV task helps understand exact road boundaries?

options.A: Image Segmentation

lecture: Lecture 3: Machine Learning Concepts and Algorithms

questions.question: What is the main difference between traditional rule-based methods and machine learning?

options.A: ML learns patterns from data automatically, while rule-based methods require explicit programming
options.B: ML is slower but more accurate
options.C: Rule-based methods can handle more complex problems
options.D: ML doesn't require data at all

questions.question: When should you consider using machine learning instead of traditional programming?

options.A: When rules are complex, change over time, or data distribution changes
options.B: When problems are simple and well-defined
options.C: When you have very little data

questions.question: Which scenario is ideal for machine learning application?

options.A: Speech recognition where rules are complex to describe
options.D: Calculating tax based on fixed percentages

questions.question: What happens when 'task rules change over time' that makes ML suitable?

options.A: ML models can adapt to new data and changing patterns
options.C: ML requires less maintenance than rule-based systems
options.D: ML doesn't need to be updated

questions.question: Why is ML better than rule-based systems when data distribution changes?

options.A: ML can adapt to new data patterns through retraining
options.D: ML works perfectly without new data

questions.question: Which type of learning uses labeled data where each input has a known correct output?

options.A: Supervised Learning

questions.question: What characterizes Unsupervised Learning?

options.A: Works with unlabeled data, finding hidden patterns without correct answers provided
options.B: Uses only labeled data with known outputs

questions.question: In Reinforcement Learning, how does the agent learn?

options.A: Through trial and error, receiving rewards for good actions and penalties for bad ones
options.B: From labeled examples provided by a teacher
options.C: By finding patterns in unlabeled data

questions.question: What is Semi-supervised Learning?

options.A: Uses a small amount of labeled data combined with a large amount of unlabeled data

questions.question: Which learning type would you use to predict whether an email is spam?

options.A: Supervised Learning

questions.question: What type of problem is 'predicting house prices based on features'?

options.A: Regression (predicting continuous values)

questions.question: Which problem type assigns inputs to one of k categories?

options.A: Classification

questions.question: What does Clustering do?

options.A: Groups unlabeled data by similarity

questions.question: What's the main difference between Classification and Regression outputs?

options.A: Classification outputs discrete classes, Regression outputs continuous values
options.C: Regression only works with numbers, Classification with text

questions.question: Which is an example of a Regression problem?

options.A: Predicting stock prices next week

questions.question: In supervised learning, what is the 'teacher'?

options.A: The labeled data that provides correct answers
options.B: The programmer who writes the rules
options.C: The test data used for evaluation

questions.question: What does the model do during supervised learning?

options.A: Learns by comparing predictions with correct answers and improves over time
options.C: Explores the environment through trial and error

questions.question: Which is an example of supervised learning for classification?

options.A: Determining if an email is spam based on labeled examples
options.C: Recommending movies based on user behavior
options.D: Learning to drive through trial and error

questions.question: What is the output of a regression model?

options.A: A continuous numerical value

questions.question: In the patient clinic example from lecture, what type of supervised learning was shown?

options.A: Classification (healthy vs sick)

questions.question: What is the main challenge in unsupervised learning?

options.A: No correct answers are provided, so evaluation is harder
options.B: Too much labeled data is required

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used for clustering?

options.A: K-means

questions.question: What does 'intra-cluster similarity' mean in clustering?

options.A: Items within the same cluster are more similar to each other
options.B: Items in different clusters are similar

questions.question: Which is an example of unsupervised learning application?

options.A: Recommending movies for users based on viewing patterns

questions.question: How does unsupervised learning handle new data?

options.A: Calculates similarity with existing samples and classifies by similarity

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of Reinforcement Learning?

options.A: Learns through interaction with environment using rewards/penalties
options.B: Requires large amounts of labeled data

questions.question: What does the 'reward function' do in RL?

options.A: Provides feedback to guide learning towards desired behavior

questions.question: What does the agent try to maximize in RL?

options.A: Cumulative reward over time

questions.question: Why is semi-supervised learning useful?

options.A: Labeled data is often expensive/time-consuming to obtain
options.B: It's always more accurate than supervised learning

questions.question: What proportion of data is typically labeled in semi-supervised learning?

options.A: Small amount of labeled, large amount of unlabeled
options.D: Equal amounts of labeled and unlabeled

questions.question: Which learning types does semi-supervised combine?

options.A: Supervised and Unsupervised Learning

questions.question: Why is RL good for robotics and gaming?

options.A: These involve sequential decisions where actions affect future states
options.B: They have lots of labeled data

questions.question: What type of learning would you use for 'defining fish of the same species' without labels?

options.A: Clustering (Unsupervised Learning)

questions.question: For 'recommending movies for users' based on viewing history without explicit ratings, which learning type?

options.A: Unsupervised Learning (finding patterns in viewing behavior)

lecture: Lecture 4: The Machine Learning Process: From Raw Data to Effective Models

questions.question: What is the complete machine learning process sequence?

options.A: Data preparation → Data cleansing → Feature extraction/selection → Model training → Model evaluation → Deployment → Feedback & iteration
options.B: Model training Data cleansing → Feature selection Deployment → Feedback
options.C: Data collection → Model training Immediate deployment

questions.question: What is the purpose of the feedback and iteration step in ML?

options.A: Gather real-world feedback and use it to improve the model iteratively
options.C: Only collect more data without model changes
options.D: Wait for the model to improve automatically

questions.question: Which step comes immediately after data cleansing?

options.A: Feature extraction and selection

questions.question: What is a 'dataset' in machine learning?

options.A: A collection of data used in ML tasks, where each piece is called a sample

questions.question: What are 'features' in a dataset?

options.A: Items or attributes that reflect the nature of a sample in a particular aspect

questions.question: What is the difference between a training set and a test set?

options.A: Training set: used for building the model; Test set: used for evaluating the learned model
options.C: Training set: for evaluation; Test set: for building

questions.question: What does 'learning' or 'training' refer to in ML?

options.A: The process of building a model from data
options.B: The process of testing a model
options.D: The process of deploying the model

questions.question: In the typical dataset composition diagram, what are the components?

options.A: Feature 1, Feature 2, Feature 3, Label

questions.question: Why is data processing crucial in machine learning?

options.A: Data determines the scope of model capabilities; all good models require good data
options.B: It's optional and can be skipped

questions.question: What is the 'curse of dimensionality'?

options.A: Having too many features (dimensions) compared with the amount of data

questions.question: What are the common operations in data preprocessing?

options.A: Data filtering, handling data loss, handling errors/abnormal values, merging data from multiple sources, data consolidation

questions.question: What does 'dirty data' typically contain?

options.A: Incompleteness, noise, inconsistency

questions.question: What is 'incompleteness' in data quality problems?

options.A: Incomplete data or lack of relevant attributes/values

questions.question: What is 'noise' in data quality problems?

options.A: Data contains incorrect records or abnormal points

questions.question: What is 'inconsistency' in data quality problems?

options.A: Data contains conflicting records

questions.question: What operations are typically used to convert data for ML models?

options.A: Encoding categorical data, converting numeric to categorical, word embedding, image processing, feature engineering
options.B: Only using raw data as is

questions.question: What is feature engineering?

options.A: Normalizing/standardizing features and creating new features from existing ones

questions.question: Why might you convert numeric data into categorical data?

options.A: To reduce the number of variable values (e.g., segmenting age data)

questions.question: Why is feature selection necessary?

options.A: Some features may be unnecessary or irrelevant to the values to be predicted

questions.question: What are the three main types of feature selection methods?

options.A: Filter methods, Wrapper methods, Embedded methods

questions.question: How do Filter methods work?

options.A: Select features based on statistical tests, evaluating each feature independently with target variable
options.B: Use model performance to score feature subsets
options.C: Build feature selection into model training

questions.question: How do Wrapper methods work?

options.A: Use a prediction model to score feature subsets based on model performance
options.D: Only consider one feature at a time

questions.question: How do Embedded methods work?

options.A: Treat feature selection as part of the modeling process itself

questions.question: What is a limitation of Filter methods?

options.A: Tend to select redundant variables because they don't consider relationships between features

questions.question: What is a limitation of Wrapper methods?

options.A: Computationally intensive because they train a new model for each feature subset

questions.question: Which feature selection method combines benefits of both filter and wrapper methods?

options.A: Embedded methods

questions.question: What are the 6 steps in building an AI model according to the lecture?

options.A: Split data → Train model → Validate model → Tune model → Deploy model Test model

questions.question: What is the purpose of splitting data into training, validation, and test sets?

options.A: Training: build model; Validation: tune model; Test: evaluate generalization capability

questions.question: What is the validation set used for?

options.A: To evaluate model effectiveness and tune the model

questions.question: What is the test set used for?

options.A: To evaluate the generalization capability of the model

questions.question: What is 'generalization' in machine learning?

options.A: The model's ability to perform well on new, unseen samples
options.B: Performing well only on training data

questions.question: What is training error?

options.A: Error of the model on the training set

questions.question: What is generalization error?

options.A: Error of the model on new samples

questions.question: What is underfitting?

options.A: When training error is large (model too simple)
options.B: When training error is small but generalization error is large
options.D: When model has too many parameters

questions.question: What is overfitting?

options.A: When training error is small but generalization error is large (model too complex)

questions.question: What is model capacity (complexity)?

options.A: The capability of the model to fit various functions

questions.question: What happens with insufficient model capacity?

options.A: Underfitting may occur (can't handle complex tasks)

questions.question: What happens with excessive model capacity?

options.A: Overfitting may occur (learns noise)

lecture: Lecture 5: Machine Learning Model Evaluation - Comprehensive Revision Questions

questions.question: What is the primary goal of machine learning?

options.A: Ensure models perform well on new, unseen samples (generalization)
options.B: Achieve perfect performance on training data only
options.C: Create the most complex model possible
options.D: Use all available features without selection

questions.question: What does "error" in machine learning refer to?

options.A: The difference between the model's prediction and the actual result

questions.question: What is training error?

options.A: The error of the model on the training set
options.B: The error on new, unseen samples

questions.question: What is generalization error?

options.A: The error of the model on new samples

questions.question: Which type of error should we aim to minimize in practical applications?

options.A: Generalization error

questions.question: What happens when model capacity is too large?

options.A: Overfitting occurs (model learns noise)

questions.question: In binary classification, what are the possible model outputs?

options.A: Correct or incorrect predictions

questions.question: What is the typical number of classes in binary classification?

options.A: Two possible classes (e.g., Dog or Cat)

questions.question: What happens in the supervised learning process for classification?

options.A: Train on labeled training data → Test on testing data → Compare predictions with ground truth

questions.question: After training, what does the model predict?

options.A: Labels for X_test (testing data)

questions.question: What are "ground truth labels" (y values)?

options.A: The actual correct labels for the test data

questions.question: What metrics can be derived from a confusion matrix?

options.A: Recall, Precision, Specificity, Accuracy, AUC-ROC

questions.question: What is the formula for accuracy?

options.A: $(TP+TN)/(TP+TN+FP+FN)$

questions.question: What does accuracy measure?

options.A: Overall correctness: total correct predictions divided by total predictions
options.B: How well we catch positive cases
options.D: How well we identify negative cases

questions.question: What is the formula for Recall?

options.A: $TP/(TP+FN)$

questions.question: What does Precision measure?

options.A: "Out of everything predicted as Positive, how many were actually correct?"
options.B: "Out of actual positives, how many were caught?"

questions.question: What is the formula for Precision?

options.A: $TP/(TP+FP)$

questions.question: What is the F1-score (F-score)?

options.A: Harmonic mean of Precision and Recall
options.B: Arithmetic mean of Precision and Recall

questions.question: When is F1-score particularly useful?

options.A: When we need to balance catching positives (Recall) and avoiding false alarms (Precision)
options.B: When we only care about accuracy

questions.question: What is the formula for F1-score?

options.A: $2 \times (Precision \times Recall) / (Precision + Recall)$

questions.question: What does AUC measure?

options.A: Overall performance of binary classifier across all thresholds

questions.question: What is a perfect classifier's AUC value?
What does an AUC of 0.5 indicate?

options.A: Random classifier (no discriminative power)

questions.question: What is underfitting?

options.A: When training error is large (model too simple)
options.B: When training error is small but generalization error is large
options.D: When model has too many parameters

questions.question: What is overfitting?

options.A: When training error is small but generalization error is large (model too complex)

questions.question: What is model capacity (complexity)?

options.A: The capability of the model to fit various functions

questions.question: What happens with insufficient model capacity?

options.A: Underfitting may occur (can't handle complex tasks)

questions.question: What happens with excessive model capacity?

options.A: Overfitting may occur (learns noise)

questions.question: What are model parameters?

options.A: Automatically learned by models from data (e.g., weights, biases)

questions.question: What are hyperparameters?

options.A: Manually set before training to control learning process

questions.question: What do hyperparameters control?

options.A: Learning rate, number of layers, batch size, regularization strength

questions.question: How do we typically find good hyperparameters?

options.A: Through hyperparameter search (grid search, random search)
options.B: They are fixed for all models

questions.question: What is cross-validation?

options.A: A statistical method to check classifier performance by splitting data

questions.question: How does basic cross-validation work?

options.A: Split data into training and validation sets, train on one, test on other
options.B: Use all data for both training and testing

questions.question: What is k-fold cross-validation?

options.A: Split dataset into K equal parts, train on K-1 folds, test on remaining fold, repeat K times
options.B: Use only one fold for everything
options.C: Train and test on same data

questions.question: What is a common choice for K in k-fold CV?

options.A: 5 or 10

questions.question: What does k-fold CV help reduce?

options.A: Bias (overfitting to one particular train/test split)

questions.question: What do we do with the k-fold CV results?

options.A: Average them to get a more stable estimate of performance

questions.question: Why is cross-validation particularly useful?

options.A: More reliable evaluation using all data for both training and testing

questions.question: In 5-fold CV with 100 samples, how many samples in each fold?

options.A: 20 samples per fold

questions.question: What does cross-validation help us choose?

options.A: The best model that generalizes well

lecture: Lecture 6: Linear Regression and Model Evaluation in Machine Learning - Comprehensive Revision Questions

questions.question: What does linear regression predict?

options.A: Continuous values

questions.question: What type of machine learning is linear regression?

options.A: Supervised learning

questions.question: What does linear regression assume?

options.A: A linear relationship between input (independent) and output (dependent) variables

questions.question: What is the independent variable in linear regression?

options.A: The predictor variable (X)

questions.question: What is the dependent variable in linear regression?

options.A: The target variable we want to predict (Y)

questions.question: Which term represents the predicted value in linear regression?

options.A: ŷ (y-hat)

questions.question: What is the simplest form of linear regression?

options.A: Simple linear regression: $y=b0+b1^{*}x$

questions.question: What is the regression line?

options.A: The best-fitting line through the data points that minimizes error

questions.question: In the salary vs. experience example, what does the regression line show?

options.A: How salary changes with experience

questions.question: What is a residual?

options.A: The difference between actual value and predicted value

questions.question: What does  (epsilon) represent in regression?

options.A: The error term (difference between actual and predicted)

questions.question: What is the "point estimate" of the error term called?

options.A: Residual

questions.question: What method does linear regression use to find the best-fitting line?

options.A: Least Squares Method

questions.question: What does the Least Squares method minimize?

options.A: Sum of squared differences between actual and predicted values

questions.question: What are the "squared differences" being minimized?

options.A: Residuals squared

questions.question: What is the hypothesis (model) in linear regression?

options.A: $\hat{y}=b0+b1^{*}x$ (for simple regression)

questions.question: What is the error for each data point?

options.A: $(\hat{y}-y)$ or $(y-\hat{y})$

questions.question: What cost function is commonly used in linear regression?

options.A: Mean Squared Error (MSE)

questions.question: What is the formula for Mean Squared Error?
What does MSE measure?

options.A: Average of squared differences between predicted and actual values

questions.question: What is simple linear regression?

options.A: One independent variable predicting one dependent variable: $y=b0+b1^{*}x$

questions.question: What is multiple linear regression?

options.A: Multiple independent variables predicting one dependent variable: $y=b0+b1^{*}\times1+b2^{*}\times2+...$

questions.question: In multiple regression equation $y=b0+b1^{*}\times1+b2^{*}\times2$, what is b0?

options.A: Constant (intercept)

questions.question: In multiple regression equation $y=b0+b1^{*}\times1+b2^{*}\times2$, what is b1?

options.A: Coefficient for variable x1

questions.question: How does adding more independent variables affect regression?

options.A: Can capture more complex relationships but risks overfitting

questions.question: What happens if we use linear regression for non-linear data?

options.A: Poor predictions due to incorrect model assumption

lecture: Lecture 8: Random Forest and Ensemble Learning Algorithms

questions.question: How is a decision tree oriented?

options.A: Upside down with root at the top

questions.question: What type of questions does a decision tree ask?

options.A: True/False questions at each node

questions.question: What is the goal of decision tree questions?

options.A: To un-mix the data or reduce uncertainty
options.B: To make the tree look complex

questions.question: How does a decision tree split data?

options.A: Into two or more subsets based on answers to questions

questions.question: What algorithm step calculates how well features split data?

options.A: Using Gini Impurity (GI)

questions.question: What is Random Forest?

options.A: A machine learning algorithm that uses many decision trees to make better predictions

questions.question: How does Random Forest combine tree results for classification?

options.A: Majority voting

questions.question: How does Random Forest combine tree results for regression?

options.A: Averaging

questions.question: What helps Random Forest avoid overfitting?

options.A: Using random data and features for each tree
options.D: Using all features all the time

questions.question: What makes Random Forest predictions more trustworthy?

options.A: Combining multiple trees reduces individual errors

questions.question: What is the first step in Random Forest algorithm?

options.A: Bootstrap Sampling: creating random subsets with replacement
options.B: Training all trees on same data

questions.question: What does "sampling with replacement" mean in bootstrap?

options.A: Same sample can appear multiple times in a subset

questions.question: How are trees constructed in Random Forest?

options.A: Each tree considers only random subset of features at each split
options.C: Trees use same features as each other

questions.question: What happens after all trees are built?

options.A: Predictions are aggregated using voting (classification) or averaging (regression)
options.D: Trees are combined into one big tree

questions.question: What does Random Forest specifically help reduce?

options.A: Overfitting and improves model accuracy

questions.question: Is Random Forest a supervised or unsupervised algorithm?

options.A: Supervised algorithm

questions.question: What happens when you increase number of trees in Random Forest?

options.A: Improves model stability and accuracy (up to a point)

questions.question: How does Random Forest differ from a single decision tree?

options.A: Introduces randomness in data and feature selection

questions.question: What assumptions does Random Forest make?

options.A: Each tree makes its own decisions, uses random data parts, needs enough data

questions.question: What is bootstrapping?

options.A: Taking random samples from data with replacement many times

questions.question: What is created through bootstrapping?

options.A: New "fake" datasets that are slightly different

questions.question: What do we calculate for each bootstrap dataset?

options.A: Results like average to understand reliability

questions.question: What does bootstrapping help us understand?

options.A: How stable or reliable our original result is

questions.question: When is bootstrapping particularly useful?

options.A: When we have small dataset

questions.question: Where is bootstrapping used in machine learning?

options.A: In Random Forests to make models more reliable

questions.question: What is ensemble learning?

options.A: Combining multiple models to improve performance

questions.question: What problem do individual models often have?

options.A: May overfit training data or underperform on unseen instances

questions.question: How do ensembles solve individual model problems?

options.A: By aggregating models and balancing their errors

questions.question: In the ensemble diagram, how are individual model predictions combined?

options.A: Through aggregation to produce final ensemble classifier

questions.question: Why do ensembles often work better than individual models?

options.A: Different models make different errors, ensemble averages them out

questions.question: What are the two main ways to build ensemble models?

options.A: Independent construction and coordinated construction

questions.question: How does independent ensemble construction work?

options.A: Each model trained separately, randomness added, results combined

questions.question: What is an example of independent ensemble construction?

options.A: Random Forest (each tree built independently)

questions.question: How does coordinated ensemble construction work?

options.A: Models built one after another, each learns from previous mistakes
options.B: All models trained at same time

questions.question: What are the three main types of ensemble classifiers?

options.A: Bagging, Boosting, Stacking

questions.question: What does "Bagging" stand for?

options.A: Bootstrap Aggregating

questions.question: How does Bagging work?

options.A: Trains multiple models independently in parallel using bootstrap samples

questions.question: What does Bagging specifically reduce?

options.A: Variance and helps prevent overfitting

questions.question: What is an advantage of Bagging?

options.A: Models trained in parallel, making it efficient

questions.question: How are bootstrap datasets created in Bagging?

options.A: By randomly sampling with replacement

questions.question: What type of base learner is often used in Bagging?

options.A: Decision tree

questions.question: How are predictions combined in Bagging?

options.A: Averaging (regression) or majority voting (classification)

questions.question: What problem does Bagging specifically address?

options.A: High variance in unstable models like decision trees

questions.question: What is Boosting?

options.A: Builds models sequentially so each learns from errors of previous ones

questions.question: How does Boosting improve models?

options.A: Improving bias and accuracy by focusing on difficult instances

questions.question: What happens to misclassified samples in Boosting?

options.A: Receive higher weights in subsequent iterations

questions.question: How long does the Boosting process continue?

options.A: For multiple iterations/specified number of models

questions.question: What is an advantage of Boosting?

options.A: Can turn weak learners into strong ones

questions.question: Where does Boosting work particularly well?

options.A: With structured data, provides high accuracy

questions.question: What type of model does Boosting typically start with?

options.A: Weak base model (e.g., shallow decision tree)

questions.question: What happens to sample weights after each iteration in Boosting?

options.A: Increased for misclassified samples

questions.question: How are predictions combined in Boosting?

options.A: Combine predictions of all models

questions.question: What is Stacking?

options.A: Combines multiple models of different types using a meta-model

questions.question: How are base models trained in Stacking?

options.A: Independently, then outputs used as inputs to meta-learner

questions.question: What does the meta-learner do?

options.A: Learns best way to merge base model predictions

questions.question: What is commonly used as the meta-learner?
